semantic_title: Sequencing of Category G89 Codes with Site-Specific Pain Codes
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 6. Chapter 6: Diseases of the Nervous System > b. Pain - Category G89 > 1) General coding information > (b) Use of Category G89 Codes in Conjunction with Site Specific Pain Codes > (ii) Sequencing of Category G89 Codes with Site-Specific Pain Codes

content.full_text: The sequencing of category G89 codes with site-specific pain codes (including chapter 18 codes), is dependent on the circumstances of the encounter/admission as follows: • If the encounter is for pain control or pain management, assign the code from category G89 followed by the code identifying the specific site of pain (e.g., encounter for pain management for acute neck pain from trauma is assigned code G89.11, Acute pain due to trauma, followed by code M54.2, Cervicalgia, to identify the site of pain). • If the encounter is for any other reason except pain control or pain management, and a related definitive diagnosis has not been established (confirmed) by the provider, assign the code for the specific site of pain first, followed by the appropriate code from category G89. (Evidence: pg no: 47, L39-L45)
content.summary: Sequencing rules for G89 and site-specific pain codes based on the reason for the encounter - pain management vs other reasons. (Evidence: pg no: 47, L39-L45)
key_concepts: Pain control encounter sequencing (Evidence: pg no: 47, L43-L44)
Non-pain management encounter sequencing (Evidence: pg no: 47, L45)
Definitive diagnosis consideration (Evidence: pg no: 47, L45)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If the encounter is for pain control or pain management, assign the code from category G89 followed by the code identifying the specific site of pain (Evidence: pg no: 47, L43-L44)
detailed_rules.explanation: For pain management encounters, G89 codes are sequenced first, followed by site-specific codes (Evidence: pg no: 47, L43-L44)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If the encounter is for any other reason except pain control or pain management, and a related definitive diagnosis has not been established (confirmed) by the provider, assign the code for the specific site of pain first, followed by the appropriate code from category G89 (Evidence: pg no: 47, L45)
detailed_rules.explanation: For non-pain management encounters without definitive diagnosis, site-specific codes are sequenced first, followed by G89 codes (Evidence: pg no: 47, L45)

workflow_steps: Step 2: If pain control/management, sequence G89 first, then site code
Step 3: If other reason and no definitive diagnosis, sequence site code first, then G89
Step 4: Apply appropriate sequencing based on encounter circumstances

code_ranges.description: Pain codes with encounter-dependent sequencing rules (Evidence: pg no: 47, L39)
usage_rules: First for pain management encounters (Evidence: pg no: 47, L43-L44)
Second for other encounters without definitive diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 47, L45)

specific_codes.description: Acute pain due to trauma (Evidence: pg no: 47, L44)
specific_codes.context: Example for pain management encounter sequencing
Example site-specific code for neck pain

references_to.title: Category G89 Codes as Principal or First-Listed Diagnosis
references_to.explanation: Builds on principal diagnosis rules with specific sequencing guidance

coding_scenarios.scenario: Encounter for pain management for acute neck pain from trauma
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient presents for pain management of acute neck pain following motor vehicle accident
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify encounter is for pain management
Step 2: Assign G89.11 (Acute pain due to trauma) first
Step 3: Assign M54.2 (Cervicalgia) second to identify site

correct_coding.sequencing: G89 first for pain management encounter
correct_coding.rationale: Pain management encounter sequences G89 first, then site code (Evidence: pg no: 47, L43-L44)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Incorrect sequencing for pain management encounter
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not recognizing pain management as reason for encounter

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient presents for evaluation of chronic back pain, no definitive diagnosis established
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient presents for evaluation of chronic lower back pain, cause undetermined
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify encounter is for evaluation, not pain management
Step 2: Note no definitive diagnosis established

correct_coding.sequencing: Site code first for non-pain management encounter
correct_coding.rationale: Non-pain management encounter without definitive diagnosis sequences site first (Evidence: pg no: 47, L45)

incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using pain management sequencing for diagnostic encounters

breakdown.G89.11: Acute pain due to trauma (first for pain management) (Evidence: pg no: 47, L44)

examples.rationale: Pain management encounter sequences G89 first (Evidence: pg no: 47, L43-L44)

warnings: Sequencing depends on encounter circumstances, not just code types (Evidence: pg no: 47, L39-L40)
best_practices: Always determine reason for encounter before sequencing codes
Consider whether definitive diagnosis has been established
common_mistakes: Using same sequencing regardless of encounter reason
Not distinguishing between pain management and diagnostic encounters
tips: Pain management encounters: G89 first, site second
Other encounters without definitive diagnosis: site first, G89 second
implementation_notes: Definitive diagnosis status affects sequencing decisions
clinical_context: Pain management is a specific type of encounter
